utterance: that he had heard they wanted a boy, and he wanted a place.
speaker: Uncle Ben Williamson

utterance: Don't you give her up, Marse Johnny; don't you nuver give her up. Ef she's wuth havin', she's wuth fightin' for; an' ef she say No, she jes beginnin' to mean Yes. Don't you give her up.
speaker: William

utterance: Where did you come from?
speaker: Judge Allen

utterance: From old Charlotte, suh; used to 'longst to de Bruces.
speaker: Uncle Ben Williamson

utterance: Can you clean up?
speaker: Judge Allen

utterance: Kin I clean up? Dat's what I come to do. Jinny ken, too.
speaker: Uncle Ben Williamson

utterance: Can you read?
speaker: Judge Allen

utterance: Well, nor, suh, not edzactly. I ain't no free-issue nigger ner preacher.
speaker: Uncle Ben Williamson

utterance: Do you get drunk?
speaker: Judge Allen

utterance: Yes, sir, sometimes.Not so often. I'ain't got nuttin to git de whiskey. But ef I's drunk, Jinny cleans up.
speaker: Uncle Ben Williamson

utterance: Who is Jinny?
speaker: Judge Allen

utterance: She's my wife.
speaker: Uncle Ben Williamson

utterance: What sort of a woman is she?
speaker: Judge Allen

utterance: She's a black woman. Oh!-she's a good sort o' ooman-a toler'ble good sort o' ooman, ef you know how to git 'long wid her. Sort o' raspy sometimes, like urr wimmens, but I kin manage her. You kin try us. Ef you don't like us we ken go. We 'ain't got no root to we foots.
speaker: Uncle Ben Williamson

utterance: You'll do. I'll try you.
speaker: Judge Allen

utterance: Jinny jes been kind o' easin' her mine.
speaker: Uncle Ben Williamson

utterance: Aye, aye, what I tell you?
speaker: Uncle Ben Williamson

utterance: Silence!
speaker: the big tipstaff

utterance: Now come 'long home wid me an' 'have yourself. I'll teach you to sling flat-iron at folks' head!
speaker: Uncle Ben Williamson

utterance: Got to go to jail!
speaker: Uncle Ben Williamson

utterance: Jedge, ken I say a wud?
speaker: Uncle Ben Williamson

utterance: Why-ah-yes. It is very unusual, but go on.
speaker: Judge Allen

utterance: Well, gent'mens, I jes wants to say (he paused, and took in the entire court-room in the sweep of his glance)—I jes wants to say dat I don't think you ought to do Jinny dat a-way. Y'all 'ain' got nuttin 't all 'ginst Jinny. She 'ain' do nuttin to you all-nuttin 't all. She's my wife, an' what she done she done to me. Ef I kin stan' it, y'all ought to be able to, dat's sho'. Now hit's dis a-way. Y'all is married gent'mens, an' yo' knows jes how 'tis. Yo' knows sometimes a ooman gits de debil in her. 'Tain't her fault; 'tis de debil's. Hit jes like wolf in cows. Sometimes dee gits in de skin an' mecks 'em kick up an' run an' mean. Dat's de way 'tis wid wimmens. I done know Jinny ever sence she wuz a little gal at home in de country. I done know how mean she is. I done know all dat, an' I done marry her, 'cuz she suit me. I had plenty o'urr gals I could 'a' marry, but I ain' want dem. I want Jinny, an' I pester her tell she had me. Well, she meaner eben 'n I think she is; but dat ain' nuttin: I satisfied wid her, an' dat's 'nough. Y'all don' know how mean she is. She mean as a narrer-faced mule. She kick an' she fight an' she quoil tell sometimes I hardly ken stay in muh house; but dat ain' nuttin. I stay dyah, an' when she git thoo I right dyah jes same as befo', an' I know den I gwine have a good supper, an' I ain' got to pester my mine 'bout nuttin. Y'all done been all 'long dyah, 'cuz y'all is married gent'mens. Well, dat's de way 'twuz turr night. Jinny been good so long, I feared she got some'n de matter wid her, an' I kind o'git oneasy, an' sort o' poke her up. But she ain't; she all right. I so glad to find her dat way, I sort o' uppish, an' when she hit me I slapped her. I didn' mean to hu't her; I jes hit her a little tap side her head, so, an' she went all to pieces in a minute. I done hurt her feelin's. Y'all knows how 'tis yo'self. Wimmen's got mighty cu'ious feelin's, ain' like chillern's nor men's. Ef you slap 'em, dey goes dat a-way. Dey gits aggervated, an' den dey got to ease dee mine. Well, Jinny she got mighty big mine, an' when she dat a-way it tecks right smart to ease it-to smoove it. Fust she done try broom, den cheer, den shovel, den skillet; but ain' none o' dem able to ease her, an' den she got to try de flat-iron. She got to do it. Y'all knows how 'tis. Ef wimmen's got to do anything dey got to do it, an' dat's all. Flat-iron don' hu't none. I 'ain' eben feel it. Hit jes knock me out muh head little while, an' I jes good as I wuz befo'. When I come to I fine dee done 'rest Jinny. Dat's what hu't me. Jinny done been easin' her mine all dese years, an' we 'ain' nuver had no trouble befo'. An' now y'all say she got to go to de pen'tentia'y. How'd y'all like somebody to sen' you' wife to pen'tentia'y when she jes easin' her mine? I ax you dat. How she gwine ease her mine dyah? I ax you dat. I know y'all gwine sen' her dyah, gent'mens, 'cuz you done say you is. I know you is, an' I 'ain' got nuttin to say 'bout it, not a wud; but all I ax you is to le' me go dyah too. I don' want stay here b'dout Jinny, an' y'all ain' gwine to know how to manage her b'dout me. I is de on'iest one kin do dat. Jinny got six chillern-little chillern-dis las' crap; she didn' hab none some sevrul years, an' den she had six. I gwine bring 'em all right up heah to y'all to teck keer on, 'cuz I gwine wid her-ef you le' me. I kyarn stan' it dyah by myself. I leetle mo' went 'stracted last night. Y'all kin have 'em, 'cuz y'all ken teck keer on 'em, an' I kyan't. I would jes like you to let her go home for a leetle while 'fo' yo' sen' her up, I jes would like dat. She got a right new baby dyah squealin' for her dis minute, an' I mighty feared hit gwine to die widout her, an' dat 'll be right hard 'pon Jinny. She 'ain' never los' but byah one, an' I had right smart trouble wid her 'bout dat. She sort o' out her head arter dat some sevrul months, till she got straight agin. I git 'long toler'ble well wid de urr chillerns, but I ain' able to nuss dat new one, an' she squeal all night. I got a ooman to come dyah an' look arter it, but she say she want Jinny, an', I think Jinny want her—I think she do. Jes let her go dyah a little while. Dat's all I want to ax you.
speaker: Uncle Ben Williamson

utterance: I would like to poll the jury.
speaker: the counsel

utterance: Is that your verdict?
speaker: the clerk

utterance: Well, judge, I thought it was; but (he looked down at his fellows) I think if I could I would like to talk to one or two of the other jurors a minute, if it is not too late. My wife's got a right new baby at home herself that squealed a little last night, and I'd like to go back to the room and think about it.
speaker: the consumptive-looking foreman

utterance: Sheriff, take the jury back to their room.
speaker: Judge Allen

utterance: I wish I had the courage,

utterance: Very handsome. That girl has a great deal of taste. So that was the reason she wanted to see my coat of arms.

utterance: That's a really lovely thing. those apple blossoms are perfect. She made that herself, and-by Jove, that's a piece of the old dress she wore that night at the Valentine ball ten years ago!
speaker: Billington

utterance: Lord! Lord! How sweet she was that night!

utterance: No, she had only her dress on her.

utterance: Oh, hang it! I'll write a valentine,
speaker: Billington

utterance: More rich than is Golconda's mine,
speaker: Billington

utterance: By Jove, this would do for either.
speaker: Billington

utterance: Oh, hang it ! I'll go to walk.
speaker: Billington

utterance: I never saw such an abstracted air. I really thought you were not going to speak to me.
speaker: unspecified

utterance: I was thinking of you at the time I believe. I was just wondering whose turnout this was, and thinking it the handsomest on the Avenue.
speaker: Billington

utterance: Isn't it lovely! Papa gave it to me as a valentine. Aren't those sorrels darlings?
speaker: unspecified

utterance: "An' who is that thryin' to break the door down now?"
speaker: Mrs. McDuffy

utterance: "An' is it breakin' the door down intoirly ye're afther?"
speaker: Mrs. McDuffy

utterance: "Live here, is it? Yis, an' that they do, an' Bridget McDuffy is the wan as knas it, too. An' lives on the fat of the lan', they do; an' gits it out of may, they do, too; may a poor widder, or as good as wan, an' not a tin-cint pace o' their money has I sane for three months; an' they pramisin' to pay me every wake, an' a-drinkin' an' a-guzzlin' them- selves up-stairs as full as St. Pathrick's well, an' borryin' all o' me best glasses an' sphoons, an' niver the manners to say wanst to may, ‘Mrs. McDuffy, will ye walk in an' wet ye' whistle?"
speaker: Mrs. McDuffy

utterance: "So Cerberus caught you?"
speaker: Henry

utterance: "By Jove! when I heard you tum- ble, I thought she was flinging you down the steps."
speaker: Henry

utterance: "Why, Henry!"
speaker: Charlie

utterance: "She really has a beautiful tem- per. She is a little ruffled this evening, ow- ing to the way Henry approached her on a small domestic matter."
speaker: Charlie

utterance: "Approached her! If you had bought the things instead of buying that beaver to put on your empty head, I should not have had to go to her. What do you fel- lows think of my giving him the money to get up the ball, and his spending it all in a beaver hat and silk handkerchiefs!"
speaker: Henry

utterance: "Besides, didn't I get the eggs and whiskey?"
speaker: Charlie

utterance: "Yes; but where's the supper?"
speaker: Henry

utterance: "I bet you this hat against your best pair of breeches 'I get it yet,"
speaker: Charlie

utterance: "Done,"
speaker: Henry

utterance: "I will wear that hat to church to-morrow."
speaker: Henry

utterance: "I told her we were going to have an Irish lord to sup with us, and I would have got everything all right if Henry had not spoilt it. Lord McCarthy, of Castle McCarthy, County Kerry, Ireland - wasn't that the name I gave?"
speaker: Charlie

utterance: "Mrs. McDuffy came from County Kerry; but rather young. Some years ago, I may observe."
speaker: Henry

utterance: "Well, you had better go and get some coal from her; for this fire is going out, I may ob- serve,"
speaker: Henry

utterance: "Where are the slats?"
speaker: Charlie

utterance: "Aren't there still four left?"
speaker: Henry

utterance: "Yes; but there are no more slats to spare. The bed feels like a gridiron now."
speaker: Charlie

utterance: "Better men than you have lain on a grid- iron. What a sybarite you are! Why not sleep on the floor? That is the natural place to sleep, anyhow.”
speaker: Charlie

utterance: "No, I'll be hanged if I do,"
speaker: Henry

utterance: "And I suppose we could not spare another chair?"
speaker: Henry

utterance: "'Why, then you must go down-stairs and get it,"
speaker: Charlie

utterance: "Down-stairs! Where? We haven't any coal down-stairs."
speaker: Henry

utterance: "We have not! Why, of course we have! Do you suppose we are going to let an old Irishwoman sleep with her coal-cellar literally bulging with coal whilst we have no fire?— entertaining a real live Irish lord too!"
speaker: Charlie

utterance: "Suppose we borrow some from Pestler,"
speaker: Henry

utterance: "Borrow of a demned petty tradesman, and the night before Christmas, too! Where is your pride? Besides, I borrowed some from him last week. Go down and get some coal."
speaker: Charlie

utterance: "What are you going to bring it up in?"
speaker: Henry

utterance: "Why, this,"
speaker: Charlie

utterance: "An' where is he? the thievin', burglin' vil- lain! Let me get at him. I'll fix him. Break-in' down me house an' robbin' me under me very eyes!"
speaker: Mrs. McDuffy

utterance: "Don't lock the door, Henry; Mrs. McDuffy will be up directly to call on us,"
speaker: Charlie

utterance: "Why, is that you, Mrs. McDuffy ?"
speaker: Charlie

utterance: "Yis, an' yis, an' yis, it is Mrs. McDuffy, an' if ye don't kna' her, I mane to make ye kna' her,"
speaker: Mrs. McDuffy

utterance: "Know you! Why, of course, I know you, Mrs. McDuffy, I have got a drop of the Irish in me meself (which was true if he was talking about whiskey). Me mither was Irish, ye kna' (dropping into the brogue). Her father was a Doherty, from County Kerry, an' I never for- gets the pretty Irish face wanst I says it. I was thinkin' of coomin' down to ask ye if ye would not faiver us by coomin' up an' joinin' us. Sure I was just sayin' to me friend here, if ye want to say the prettiest Irishwoman this side of the say, it's down-stairs she is, says I, an' maybe we kin git her to come up, says I. An' I'll joust stale down, says I, an' break into her coal-box, says I, an' fling a pace or two down the steps, says I, an' that will fetch her up, says I, to say what the divil is the mather av it, says I, an' ye kin say how pretty she is yourself, says I."
speaker: Charlie

utterance: "git away wid his Irish blarney—not that wanst she had not had her looks as well as the best of them before so much throuble came upon her."
speaker: Mrs. McDuffy

utterance: "Throuble, is it? An' throuble indade you have had, Mrs. McDuffy, but it hasn't touched yer looks. Sure it's yer own darther folks takes you for any time. Why, me friend here was just sayin' to me: 'Who is that likely Irish leddy that let me in the door down-stairs? An' is she a girl or is she mar- ried?' says he. 'An' if she's married, is she a widow?' says he. An' I says to him: 'If she was a widow, do ye think she'd be so long,' says I, 'an' me in the house too?' says I. But coom in. I'd like to inthroduce ye to me friend Lord McCarthy, av Castle McCarthy, County Kerry, Ireland. Ye knows all about the Mc- Carthys, I knows, Mrs. McDuffy. You was a Doherty; an' 'Toim was,' says my mither to me wanst-'toim Charlie, me boy, when the Dohertys cou lahs in Kerry."
speaker: Charlie

utterance: "I always boss the ranch."
speaker: Relius

utterance: "They like it, sir. All women are slaves, and need a master."
speaker: Relius

utterance: "More waffles, Mr. Relius?"
speaker: Patsy

utterance: "Another cup of coffee, Mr. Relius?"
speaker: Patsy

utterance: "You must hold a woman up to her duty, sir. You must boss the ranch."
speaker: Relius

utterance: "Afraid!"
speaker: Relius

utterance: "Patsy, I have unfortunately mislaid my stud-buttons. I wish you would hunt for them."
speaker: Relius

utterance: "Patsy, my shirt-studs have got mislaid; I want you to hunt for them."
speaker: Relius

utterance: "Patsy, what in the devil have you done with my shirt-studs? Get them for me, and here- after let them alo-"
speaker: Relius

utterance: "Oh, Patsy, if you should happen to come across any shirt-buttons on the floor to- day when you are sweeping, will you please put them up on my bureau for me?"
speaker: Relius

utterance: "Yes, sir,"
speaker: Patsy

utterance: "Aha! did you hear that? Who says I am afraid of Patsy? Do you see how I boss the ranch?"
speaker: Relius

utterance: "A race to the other end—you that side, I this,"
speaker: unspecified

utterance: "Are you going?"
speaker: unspecified

utterance: "Yes."
speaker: unspecified

utterance: "Is it late?"
speaker: unspecified

utterance: "I do not know."

utterance: "Why are you going, then ?"
speaker: unspecified

utterance: "Because I wish to go."
speaker: unspecified

utterance: "Will you take me to my chaperon?"
speaker: unspecified

utterance: "With pleasure."
speaker: unspecified

utterance: "With pleasure?"
speaker: unspecified

utterance: "With great pleasure."
speaker: unspecified

utterance: "You are not very civil."
speaker: unspecified

utterance: "I had not intended to be."
speaker: unspecified

utterance: "Do you think—"
speaker: unspecified

utterance: "Sometimes. This evening, for instance. There is your chaperon."
speaker: unspecified

utterance: "I did not think you—"
speaker: unspecified

utterance: "So I supposed. You made a mistake. Good-bye."
speaker: unspecified

utterance: "Good-bye?"
speaker: unspecified

utterance: "Yes. Good-bye."
speaker: unspecified

utterance: "Now I tell you there's such a thing as being too thorough,"
speaker: Judge Allen

utterance: "'Your Honor,' he said, 'I came to see you about that divorce suit.'"
speaker: unspecified

utterance: "'Well, what about it? I asked, sharp- ly, getting ready to pitch into him; but he was so meek I held up. He just shook his head."
speaker: Judge Allen

utterance: "'Your Honor, that was the cruelest decree your Honor ever made. You didn't know about it, or your Honor wouldn't 'a' done it. Why, your Honor, all that fuss I made was jist put on. I wanted it jist as bad as my wife. Why, we had arranged everything, and we was both ready to git married ag'in directly. We was agoin' to have a double wedding. She was agoin' to marry a sto'keeper what makes three hundred dollars a year, and I was agoin' to marry a lady as has considerable propity. She is got a hundred and twenty- three acres o' lan', and two cows, and a hoss. She broke off one engagement to marry me, and the man is a-suin' her for breach, and now she is agoin' to sue me for breach too, and I don't know what to do.'"
speaker: unspecified

utterance: "When was it?"
speaker: unspecified

utterance: "Does any of you think I look like a felon ?"
speaker: the Governor

utterance: Hold on; come back here.
speaker: the guard

utterance: What do you want?
speaker: the narrator

utterance: I wants you, and I wants you quick. Come here.
speaker: the guard

utterance: Well, what do you want with me?
speaker: the narrator

utterance: I'm goin' to take you to the warden.
speaker: the guard

utterance: But I won't go. I don't want to go to the warden, and I won't go.
speaker: the narrator

utterance: You won't? Well, we'll see if you won't. If you don't, you'll git a load o' buckshot in you.
speaker: the guard

utterance: I am a visitor up here.
speaker: the narrator

utterance: Yes, no doubt; that's why I wants you. I wants you to finish out your visit. We can't bar to part with you. Walk along thar.
speaker: the guard

utterance: But
speaker: the narrator

utterance: But nothing; you don't want no "but" but this.
speaker: the guard

utterance: March on.
speaker: the guard

utterance: Look here; I'm the Governor of the State.
speaker: the narrator

utterance: You're a pretty-looking Gov'nor, ain't you?
speaker: the guard

utterance: Well, Gov'nor, I'm glad to see you; I'm gwine to help you finish out yo' term. Walk along thar and shet up yer jaw. I'm gittin' kinder tired on it, and I've a good mind to let you have a load of buckshot anyways, jest to teach you manners.
speaker: the guard

utterance: What became of the guard?
speaker: one

utterance: He's my manager on my farm, and he still makes me march straight.
speaker: the Gov'ner

utterance: Why, I thought you were at school?
speaker: his master

utterance: Nor, suh; I got 'nough edication.
speaker: Uncle Jack Scott

utterance: I tell you de fac', Marse Conn. I is too ole to be whupt by a ooman, an' a po' white ooman at dat.
speaker: Uncle Jack Scott

utterance: Or, poppa, de teacher say you mus' git me a geography.
speaker: Jawnie

utterance: Geog'aphy-geog'aphy. Marse Conn, whut is dat? Whut is a geog'aphy?
speaker: Uncle Jack Scott

utterance: A geography? Why, a geography is a-is a book-a book that tells about places, and where they are, and so on.
speaker: the Colonel

utterance: Yas, suh; now I onderstands.
speaker: Uncle Jack Scott

utterance: I say, boy, you tell de teacher I say you better stick to you' a-b ab's an' you' e-b eb's, an' let geog'aphy alone. You knows de way now to de spring an' de wood-pile an' de mill, an' when you gits a little bigger I's gwine to show you de way to de hoe-handle an' de cawn-furrer, an' dat's all de geog'aphy a nigger's got to know.
speaker: Uncle Jack Scott

utterance: There is no security in the world like the reputation of being worthless. With it a man can talk love to any girl he pleases, and the girl likes him, too.
speaker: Buck

utterance: Got religion, and could not stand the law.
speaker: Buck

utterance: I heard you could not stand the law, but I did not hear it was religion. I heard it was holding a man up-robbery.
speaker: the narrator

utterance: It was of his girl. You know I used to be a deuce of a fool about women; am one now, for that matter, about one, at least; would not give a cent for a man who was not. Well, I used to be awfully in love with a little girl-the preacher's daughter. Pretty as a puppy! She liked me, too; but I used to kind of knock liquor those days, and her old folks were down on me. That was all right; and at last she began to try to save me. I had her then. Nothing to help a man with a woman like having her try to save him. Well, I was getting along all right; but she had a fellow coming to see her, an old fellow from town with a big pile. I had seen him once or twice before, and I took it into my head that she was liking him. I got to cutting up about it, and the first thing I knew she had sent me flying. I got on a spree, and stayed there till I heard one evening that he had come to see her. I sobered up, and went around to the hotel to find out out him. I found that he had taken the private parlor, and had sent a note around by Link to my girl. Link was my nigger. I owned him body and soul; he would have committed murder for me. So I got hold of him and cross-questioned him. The snow was on the ground, and I found Frasher had written to ask Miss Lizzie to go sleigh-riding with him.
speaker: Buck

utterance: Did she look pleased?'
speaker: Buck

utterance: Yas, suh, dat she did; an' I hear' her calling Mincie to meck up good fire in de parlor toreckly.'
speaker: Link

utterance: I swore. I think I did. I believe I used to swear in those days.
speaker: Buck

utterance: I believe you did. Go on.
speaker: the narrator

utterance: Well, Link noticed it and consoled me.
speaker: Buck

utterance: He gwine teck her sleigh-ridin' by moonlight. He up-stairs gitting ready now.'
speaker: Link

utterance: Halt!'
speaker: Buck

utterance: He did so, and asked what I wanted. I told him that he could not go in there, that Miss Lizzie was sick.
speaker: Buck

utterance: Why, I have an engagement to go sleigh-riding with her.
speaker: Frasher

utterance: I told him that I knew that; but I had later intelligence, and she was too unwell to go out that evening. I had it from her own lips, and as her friend I could not allow her to be disturbed. This set him back a good deal; but he began to bluster. He 'would go in there,' and he 'wished to know who I was,' etc. I just pulled out my old pistol and shoved it up under his nose. You ought to have seen him! A keg of powder could not have set it off, but it looked like a cannon. Then I began to lecture him on the sin of persecuting a poor girl like he was doing-an old thing with a dyed mustache like him. You never heard such a lecture in your life. I preached like the doctor. Presently he said he would go back to the hotel, he was catching cold. I told him no, I could not let him go back just yet, but that I had some whiskey. He said he never touched whiskey. I told him that neither did I, but I had brought this along to keep him from catching cold, and he must drink it. He turned to Link and asked him in an undertone if he thought I really would shoot him.
speaker: Buck

utterance: Yas, suh,' said Link. 'Marse Buck 'ain't got a bit better sense 'n to shoot you. He 'ain't got no sense about shooting folks, noway.'
speaker: Link

utterance: Well, sir, you never saw such a drink as he took. I don't believe he had had a drop in a year. I thought he was going to the bottom of the bottle. The next thing I did, I chucked him into the sleigh, and jumped in after him. Link jumped out as I grabbed the reins, and the horses went off with a bolt. They were the finest sleigh team you ever saw, and I let 'em go. You never heard a man pray so in all your life. When we got back it was about half-past eleven, and he was as mellow as an apple. I put him to bed, and went down to the doctor's. The lights were still burning in the parlor, and I walked in. Miss Lizzie was sitting before the fire with her little red shoes on the fender and her furs on a chair, pretending to read. I told her she had just as well take off those geranium leaves and put out those lights; that her old beau with his dyed mustache was in bed drunk, and his team had had all the moonlight driving they could stand that night. Whoop! but she was mad. She never spoke to me till I went back there; but she never spoke to him again at all. He went home next day, and died soon afterwards. Ben Brice said it was pneumonia; but I don't think it was. Lizzie and I both agree it was old age.
speaker: Buck

utterance: Marse Buck, Miss Lizzie say you can bring de gent'man up now; she done put on her geramium leabes.
speaker: Link

utterance: Boys, if you think I am a good 'nigger,' you ought to see me as a villain. You do not know what a villanous villain I am. It was the first character I ever played.
speaker: Chad

utterance: Dat's him. Nor, not dat one; dat one—dat fat one over dyah.
speaker: Uncle Tony

utterance: Yo'-all let my chile alone!
speaker: mammy

utterance: Knock him down, Marse Charlie, knock him down! Wait; I'm comin'.
speaker: Uncle Tony

utterance: Marse Charlie, you didn't steal dem things sho 'nough, did you?
speaker: Uncle Tony

utterance: No, of course not.'
speaker: Chad

utterance: I tole you so; I tole you so. I tole dem other niggers so up dem stairs dyah. 'Twas dat other man heself-I tole em so.'
speaker: mammy

utterance: Marse Charlie, your pa never would 'a' stood no sich thing as dat. He never'd 'a' let no man lay a han' 'pon him in dis wull!'
speaker: Uncle Tony

utterance: Why, that was in the play. Don't you see?'
speaker: Chad

utterance: Mighty curiousome sort of play. Have a man knock you down and stomp all over you like dat, and then dar'sn' even raise your han' 'bout it. I bound your pa would 'a' knocked his head offn any man that laid his han' 'pon him.'
speaker: Uncle Tony

utterance: 'Well, he 'bleeged to git a livin','
speaker: mammy

utterance: Mighty hard way to git a livin',' said Uncle Tony, suspiciously. 'I glad old marster 'ain' know nuttin' 'bout it, dat's all.'
speaker: Uncle Tony

utterance: Well, bring him in, anyhow; I will see about it.
speaker: the judge

utterance: Is that the man? Did that man steal a steer?
speaker: the judge

utterance: Have you any counsel?
speaker: the judge

utterance: Have you any lawyer?
speaker: the judge

utterance: Nor, suh.
speaker: Mannie Johnson

utterance: if my other clients could wait a little while.
speaker: the judge

utterance: I think my other clients could wait; that I always made my clients wait my own pleasure (they had then been waiting some months).
speaker: the narrator

utterance: Have you any witnesses?
speaker: the narrator

utterance: Nor, suh.
speaker: Mannie Johnson

utterance: Can you get any if I get a continuance- if I get the case put off till next month?
speaker: the narrator

utterance: I don' know ;-nor, suh.
speaker: Mannie Johnson

utterance: Well, I think we are ready; we might as well go into trial.
speaker: the narrator

utterance: Well, I did the best I could for you.
speaker: the narrator

utterance: The only thing for us to do now is to get an appeal. I will take it up to the higher court, and fight it through for you. But it will take some money, because there are costs, and of course you ought to pay me a fee if you can.´´Have you got any money at all?
speaker: the narrator

utterance: Nor, sur; ef I had, I'd 'a' got me a lawyer !
speaker: Mannie Johnson

utterance: I jest gwine to give you up.
speaker: Pettigrew

utterance: Well, heah me.
speaker: Andrew

utterance: Yaas, heah you! Ef you hadn't been heah, you know what I'd done wid you?
speaker: Pettigrew

utterance: Yaas, I know.
speaker: Andrew

utterance: You done 'member the times I done laid hick'ry upon yo' back, down yonder, 'ain't you?
speaker: Pettigrew

utterance: Yaas, I 'member.
speaker: Andrew

utterance: Well, now, come 'long, an' don' you open yo' mouf 'cep' as I tells you; if you does, I'll-
speaker: Pettigrew

utterance: Walk!
speaker: Andrew

utterance: Wade!
speaker: Andrew

utterance: You kin talk now.
speaker: Andrew

utterance: Why'n't you talk?
speaker: Andrew

utterance: You cold? I'll warm you.
speaker: Andrew

utterance: Don't you try it.
speaker: Andrew

utterance: Le' me heah what you warn me to tell de meetin'.
speaker: Andrew

utterance: I don' warn you to tell 'em nuttin.
speaker: Pettigrew

utterance: Yaas, you does; 'cause you said so. Didn't you say so?
speaker: Andrew

utterance: Yaas, but I don' warn it now. Andrew, ef you'll le' me off I won't trouble you no more; I won't take you back to the 'sylum. I'll let you 'lone; I swah I will.
speaker: Pettigrew

utterance: Humph! Le' me heah you speak.
speaker: Andrew

utterance: Say yo' pra'rs, den.
speaker: Andrew

utterance: I'll speak.
speaker: Pettigrew

utterance: All right; begin.
speaker: Andrew

utterance: Tell 'em 'bout me.
speaker: Andrew

utterance: What mus' I tell 'em?
speaker: Pettigrew

utterance: Tell 'em what a nice white gent'man I is.
speaker: Andrew

utterance: Dat's enuff. Now tell 'em how you gwine treat me down yonder at de 'sylum.
speaker: Andrew

utterance: How many licks you hit me down dar?
speaker: Andrew

utterance: I-I-I don' know; I mighty sorry I hit you any.
speaker: Pettigrew

utterance: I is too. I don' know how many dey wuz, but I know 'twuz mo'n a hunderd; I know dat; an' I gwine hit you a clean hunderd to even 'em up.
speaker: Andrew

utterance: You see dem switches? Well, I warn you to write me a letter, an' ef you'll write it right, mebby I'll let you off ; meb- by I will. You know you writes mighty good, 'cause you's got a heap o' eddication. You wuz brought up in de house, an' I warn't nut- tin but a steer-driver. You's a yaller man, an' I ain't nuttin but a ugly, big-mouf, black nigger. I done see you write, you know, 'cause you writ me a valentine once, you 'member. You cyahs pen an' ink 'roun' wid you, jes like muh ole marster used to do when he went to court. You got 'em in yo' pocket now, an' now I warn you to write.
speaker: Andrew

utterance: I will. What you warn me to write? Who mus' I write to?
speaker: Pettigrew

utterance: Well, I warn you to write to de meetin'.
speaker: Andrew

utterance: I warn you to write it mighty good. Ef you don't, I's gwine to kill you right heah.
speaker: Andrew

utterance: Ef you wuz to kill me dey'd hang you.
speaker: Pettigrew

utterance: Dey don't hang 'stracted folks. I done larnt dat at de 'sylum, an' you know you's de one dat tol' 'em I wuz 'stracted.
speaker: Andrew

utterance: I'll write.
speaker: Pettigrew

utterance: I's gwine cyah it to muh little Johnnie fust. He kin read writin' mighty good; jes ez good ez you kin. An' of dey's anything wrong, er ef he cyarn't read it, I's gwine to let you starve to death right heah.
speaker: Andrew

utterance: What you warn me to write?
speaker: Pettigrew

utterance: Well, I warn yor o write 'em what a nice, white, colored gent man I is, jes like you done said to me heah, an' dat I ain't no mo' 'stracted den you is; an' I warn you to tell 'em dat you done had to go right back to de 'sylum, an' dat you done git de word fum Wash'n'ton dat dey's all to vote to-morrow fer muh young marse John-
speaker: Andrew

utterance: Nem mine; I don' b'lieve I warn dat any- ways; I is a 'stracted nigger, an' I ruther burn you a little anyways.
speaker: Andrew

utterance: Begin by tellin' 'em what a nice gent'man I is.
speaker: Andrew

utterance: Now read it.
speaker: Andrew

utterance: Dat's it. Now tell 'em how you's got to go right back to de 'sy- lum. Now read it. Arn harh !
speaker: Andrew

utterance: Now tell 'em how de word done come fum Wash'n'- ton, an' dey mus' vote fer muh young mars- ter, an' do ev'ything jes like I say.
speaker: Andrew

utterance: Now sign yo' name to it, an' 'dress it to de meetin', to Brer Johnson; 'cause I ain't no great han' at foldin'. But don' seal it. I gwine git muh little Johnnie to read it; he can seal it; an' ef dee's a word wrong in it, I gwine to lef' you heah to starve to death. You 'member 'bout dat valentine?
speaker: Andrew

utterance: You ain' gwine to lef' me heah in dis place by myself, is you?
speaker: Pettigrew

utterance: Yaas; you'll have plenty of company. Evil sperrits all aroun' heah, thick as dem bushy hyahs on yo' head; I sees 'em heah any time; two on 'em over yonder now, a-settin' upon dat tombstone grinnin' at you.
speaker: Andrew

utterance: Good- evenin', marster. Hope you's well dis evenin'. Dey ain' gwine hu't you till I come back, ef you keep right quiet; ef you don', dey'll roas' you right whar you settin'. I gwine to leab de fire heah fer 'em. Jes keep yo' eye on him good, marster, tell I come back.
speaker: Andrew

utterance: wa'n't no gre't hand at countin'.
speaker: Uncle Peter

utterance: I reckon, Marse Henry, you had better count dat over. I'spec' it is all dyah, 'cause I hold my hand out to him right study after he done count once, and looked mighty wise until he counted it over agin and said, 'Dat's right,' and den I come 'long; but I reckon you better count it over.
speaker: Uncle Peter

utterance: Why, what's the matter, Uncle Peter?
speaker: Marse Henry

utterance: Doesn't she pull well?
speaker: Marse Henry

utterance: Oh yes, suh, she pull enough. I 'ain't got no quoil wid Rasmus 'bout dat. She pull well as any mule I ever see, 'cep' de ole mule-I never see a mule pull like him-but she is de meanes' mule in de wull. She always pull de wrong way, and she won't back a step to save yo' life: she jes like a 'ooman. Ef you want her to go one way, she want to go turr torectly. Ef you want her to back, she want to go for- rard; ef you want her to go forrard, she won't move till she done back over de house. I's done broke more whipstaffs over her head den I could cut on the ole place.
speaker: Uncle Peter

utterance: try her jest a little longer.
speaker: Uncle Peter

utterance: whar she come from.
speaker: Uncle Peter

utterance: Uncle Peter, why do you call her Rasmus ?
speaker: Marse Henry

utterance: I calls her Rasmus, Marse Henry, 'cause Rasmus is a mule-name, and I gwine knock her head off too ef she don't mind.
speaker: Uncle Peter

utterance: Oh yes, you black Sattan, you! I know you! You done cost me ten dollars once, and you jest tryin' to git me agin. I knows you. You done had me down dere in de police cote 'bout hittin' you over your black head, and git ten dollars right out of my pocket, and you jest tryin' to make me hit you agin. But you ain't gwine do it, I tell you. You knows dem Cruel S'ciety Ani- mals is lookin' 'round here, and you jest want me to pay you anurr ten dollars agin. I'd like to bust your black brains out, but I wouldn't tetch you to save your life. Back, fool! Don't you hear me?
speaker: Uncle Peter

utterance: Uncle Peter, I reckon we had better sell that mule and get another one that will back.
speaker: Marse Henry

utterance: Sell her? Sell Rasmus? Nor, suh. Marse Henry, dat's de best mule in dis town. She got de debbel in her, dat's all. You lef her to me. I'll make her back. I'll breck her.
speaker: Uncle Peter

utterance: Yes, you black Sat- tan, you better had back. You heah what he says? I's de only one done save you. Nem mind; next time he want to sell you I'm gwine to let you go. He'd sell you long ago ef I'd let him. I jest gwine to try you a little long- er. I boun' den you will find somebody dat 'll make you back, and den you'll know how good I wuz to you.
speaker: Uncle Peter

utterance: Well, here is a letter.
speaker: the associate editor

utterance: Did you read it?
speaker: the associate editor

utterance: No. It's ten pages, and I have only one lifetime
speaker: the editor

utterance: I knew it.
speaker: the associate editor

utterance: But it's a woman, and she says that she is pining for intellectual companionship.
speaker: the associate editor

utterance: For the intellectual companionship of a young magazine editor.
speaker: the editor

utterance: Where the mischief is it? Here, find it if you can.
speaker: the editor

utterance: I'll wager that she is a tall and vinegary dame who lets her husband eat sour bread and her children wear undarned stock- ings, while she writes poems on 'The Eternal Adolescence of the Infinite.' By - the- way, where is the poem?
speaker: the editor

utterance: I bet she is not; she is a young, fresh, en- thusiastic girl with large blue eyes and a rose- leaf skin, and she teaches school and supports a widowed mother and two little sisters, and sends her younger brother to college, and he bullies her, and she writes poems of Lilacs and the Sunset.
speaker: the associate editor

utterance: What's the name ?
speaker: the associate editor

utterance: J. L. Speritt,' as well as I can make it out.
speaker: the editor

utterance: But where is the poem ?
speaker: the associate editor

utterance: Isn't this it?
speaker: the editor

utterance: Yes, this does look like the same hand. It must have fallen into the basket.
speaker: the associate editor

utterance: It is written on both sides, and does not appear to have any postage enclosed for its return. Perhaps that was the reason it was thrown there.
speaker: the editor

utterance: Perhaps. You might at least have taken the trouble to read it, for the poor young thing will expect an answer anyhow. I wouldn't be as hard-hearted and unsympathetic as you for anything; and be- sides, I have no doubt the poem is at least up to the average.
speaker: the associate editor

utterance: I do not deny that. Let's see. Read a little of it if you can. What is it called?
speaker: the editor

utterance: Ode to What is this?
speaker: the associate editor

utterance: Sour Bread?
speaker: the editor

utterance: Not at all. 'To-to'-___
speaker: the associate editor

utterance: The Lilac at Sunset?
speaker: the editor

utterance: No. 'To-My Affinity.'
speaker: the associate editor

utterance: Infinity - the Adolescence of Infinity. I told you that was it.
speaker: the editor

utterance: Well, that supports the sour-bread theory, anyhow. Go ahead.
speaker: the editor

utterance: 'Oh, thou who dwellest from me far, Through all the lonely, languorous hours Thou art to me a shining star 'Mid amaranthine bowers.'
speaker: the associate editor

utterance: How many pages are there? What do you think we ought to pay for that?
speaker: the editor

utterance: Well, it is not very- But she's young.
speaker: the associate editor

utterance: It strikes me as quite very,' but you are the poet's friend, and you can do as you like.
speaker: the editor

utterance: Well, I am sincerely sorry for the poor soul, and I'll take it. We need not publish it.
speaker: the associate editor

utterance: All right, but it would be a great deal better to write frankly and tell her the thing's rot, and that she'd better darn her children's stockings and see that the bread is sweet.
speaker: the editor

utterance: What is it—a raking from the poetess?
speaker: the editor

utterance: Well, yes, that's just what it is.
speaker: the associate editor

utterance: Well, I don't want to talk to any young woman; I did not come here for that. I've got five children older than you. I want to see the editor, and I am going to.
speaker: Mrs. Spinks

utterance: Which is the poetry - editor? Or maybe you are both the gentlemen! Well, I have come to know what you have done with that poem I sent you months ago, and which you accepted, and have suppressed.
speaker: Mrs. Spinks

utterance: Madam, will you take a seat?
speaker: the associate editor

utterance: Well, what have you done with my poem?
speaker: Mrs. Spinks

utterance: Madam, that is the poetry editor.
speaker: the chief

utterance: Ah! Well, I'm glad to find the right person. And my name is not Speritt, nor Spirit, nor Brandy, nor anything like it, though I have no doubt you are quite familiar with all those names. My name is Spinks, Mrs. Spinks, and a very good respectable name it is, too, even if it is not as aristocratic as the one I gave up to take it, which was Rowlings -though, no doubt, you never heard of it, as you must be giving up all your time to reading the stuff you publish, which is enough to make any one sick who has a grain of the divine afflatus in her soul-being second-cousin once removed to Colonel Spangles, if you ever heard of him, as no doubt you are ready to claim you have, being on the Governor's staff for three years, till he took the fever and died, leaving one of the biggest fortunes in the State, and six children, and a widow, who gives herself as many airs as if she wa'n't old Sam Malony's daughter that kept the bar at Twenty-second Street. Well, I want to tell you that I know my rights, and I mean to have them. If Mr. Spinks had had a grain of manhood in him he'd have come down here and had that poem published in the very next number of the mag- azine after you suppressed it; but he hasn't. But I have, and I've consulted a lawyer, and he says it's a clear case, and I can get dam- ages, and big damages at that, and I'm going to, and he's one of the best lawyers in the country, and a great friend of mine. What have you done with it?
speaker: Mrs. Spinks

utterance: Madam, we shall not be able to publish your poem. It was accepted under a mistake, and we will return it to you.
speaker: the chief

utterance: What!
speaker: Mrs. Spinks

utterance: The poetry editor has it and will return it to you, and you can keep the money we sent you in payment for the time we have had pos- session of it.
speaker: the chief

utterance: Well, I am glad to get it back on any terms. If I were not too much of a lady ever to be able to quarrel, I should give you a piece of my mind about it; but I never could quar- rel.
speaker: Mrs. Spinks

utterance: No, madam; your forte is poetry.
speaker: the associate editor

utterance: Thank you, I don't want any compliments from you, sir.
speaker: Mrs. Spinks

utterance: Good-morning, sir. I know a gentleman when I see him
speaker: Mrs. Spinks

utterance: Thou art to me a shining star 'Mid amaranthine bowers,
speaker: the editor

utterance: The bread was sour, after all, wasn't it?
speaker: the associate editor

utterance: Do you think I do not know what is due to a court, sir? I was sheriff before you were born.
speaker: Old Jerry

utterance: Yes, sir, no deputy either -High Sheriff, who made deputies, sir.
speaker: Old Jerry

utterance: Which is r than I can say for every one in this room,
speaker: Old Jerry

utterance: There is one infamous rascal in this room.
speaker: Old Jerry

utterance: I don't refer to you, your Worship, or you, on you, sir.
speaker: Old Jerry

utterance: I know too well what is due to the court; and I don't mean you, either, sir: I knew your father, and he was a gentleman. I know you've been trying to help rob me of my house all these years, but I don't blame you; that's your business that you are paid for. And I don't mean you, or you, addressing the doctors: if I were speaking of fools, I might not be able to over- look you. I don't mean you, Mr. Sheriff, and I don't mean myself.
speaker: Old Jerry

utterance: I'm back, you see.
speaker: Old Jerry

utterance: Yes; how is it?
speaker: the counsel

utterance: Well, you see, when I got to the asylum where that rascal got me sent the board was in session, and I knew most of them, and their fathers before them; and they asked me what I was doing there, and I made a clean breast of the whole thing—all about that scoundrel who has been robbing me, and you, and those two other fools, and all; and that I had a damned sight more sense than all of you put together; and they said they knew you all, and that I was right.
speaker: Old Jerry

utterance: I was not a particle superstitious in my early days, but I had a singular experience once.
speaker: unspecified

utterance: I'ain' ever been there, and I don't want to go.
speaker: unspecified

utterance: Too many ghosts there.
speaker: unspecified

utterance: They say that old lady can be seen there any time in broad daylight, and that old negro too; and they'd be sure to be there now the place has been shut up so long.
speaker: unspecified

utterance: That's your place.
speaker: Tommy

utterance: Your sarvent, mistis,'
speaker: the old negro man

utterance: 'What do you want?'
speaker: narrator

utterance: 'I am the butler, ma'am,'
speaker: the old negro man

utterance: 'Do you live here?
speaker: narrator

utterance: Yes, ma'am; dat is, I did live heah,'
speaker: the old negro man

utterance: 'It is time for me to go. Do you see my vehicle out there?'
speaker: narrator

utterance: 'Lord, master! You is like old mistis,'
speaker: Uncle Benny

utterance: 'Am I? Like my grandmother?'
speaker: narrator

utterance: 'Norm; like you' pa's grandma-like dat one whar hang on de wall, an' walk all 'bout dyah, and come down and set in her big cheer in de parlor.'
speaker: Uncle Benny

utterance: 'But you never saw her?'
speaker: narrator

utterance: "'Ain't I? Yes, 'm! I is, too. Done see her and talk to her too. You know my granddaddy he wuz de butler dyah in her time, jes like I wuz in you' pa's time, an' dee say I is jes like him; maybe dat's de reason she so frien❜ly to me. I done see her right in broad daylight; I see her settin' in her big cheer, an' I see her when she come out an' tuck her kerrige to drive back to the graveyard. You know she so proud she have her kerrige even to drive herself from de graveyard to the house, and you is jes like her.'
speaker: Uncle Benny

utterance: 'Yes, my father always said I was like her.'"
speaker: narrator

utterance: "When cat woan' notice rat, den look out,"
speaker: Uncle Isaac

utterance: "That ole drunk fool 'll hold out jest out o' pure cussedness,"
speaker: Charlie

utterance: "Uncle Isaac, you know you are three times as old as Rachel,"
speaker: Charlie

utterance: "and Dick is just the right age."
speaker: Charlie

utterance: "Dat's so much de better,"
speaker: Uncle Isaac

utterance: "'I'll know how to manage her; 'ooman and chillern needs management; hit's jes like physic to 'em. I got de physic for her.'
speaker: Uncle Isaac

utterance: "I'm going to tell Rachel,"
speaker: Charlie

utterance: "You know you beat your other wives scandalously."
speaker: Charlie

utterance: "Dat's some lie o' dat black trundle-bed-trash nigger Stable-Dick,"
speaker: Uncle Isaac

utterance: "I'll trick him if he fool wid me. I jes keep dem switches to whup my cat.'"
speaker: Uncle Isaac

utterance: "Uncle Isaac, if you'll give Rachel up I'll pay you."
speaker: Charlie

utterance: "How much you gwine gi' me?"
speaker: Uncle Isaac

utterance: "Well, I've got a dollar and a half, and I'll get another dollar in my stocking Christmas morning."
speaker: Charlie

utterance: "Is you got any ole umbrella you kin gi' me?"
speaker: Uncle Isaac

utterance: "No-o; but I think I could get mamma to give me one. There are several in the house."
speaker: Charlie

utterance: "'Well, I tell you what I'll do: if you'll go and git me de dollar an' a half right now, and 'll git me de best umbrella you kin, an' 'll promise me to gi' me your dollar Christmas mornin', I'll see 'bout it.'"
speaker: Uncle Isaac

utterance: "Yes, I gwine see 'bout it, an' dat's all I is gwine do."
speaker: Uncle Isaac

utterance: "Whiskey tas'e mighty good when you been dry long time,"
speaker: Uncle Isaac

utterance: "Hi! what dat?"
speaker: Uncle Isaac

utterance: "Heah, wake up, Tormy!'
speaker: Uncle Isaac

utterance: "Nem mind; I gwine git mistis for you, and ef she don' treat you well, I gwine gi' her hickory.'"
speaker: Uncle Isaac

utterance:
"I went down to Helltown,
Found de deble chained down,
Oh, Loo John! oh, Loo!
I hitch' him to my horse-cart,
And put him in a long trot,
Oh, Loo John ! oh, Loo!"
speaker: Uncle Isaac

utterance: "Don't you see dat rat, fool?"
speaker: Uncle Isaac

utterance: "Well, dat's de curisomest thing I ever see,"
speaker: Uncle Isaac

utterance: "Dat's a rat, sho'! but I 'ain' never see Tormy do dat away befo'. I's gwine to see ef dat's a rat.'"
speaker: Uncle Isaac

utterance: "Well, befo' de King!'
speaker: Uncle Isaac

utterance: "Dat rat look might❜ly to me like he was flyin',"
speaker: Uncle Isaac

utterance: "Heah, le' me put dis thing down,"
speaker: Uncle Isaac

utterance: "What dat? I done heah 'bout folks comin' down chimbley Christmas, but I 'ain' never liked it. Master, please don' come down heah,'"
speaker: Uncle Isaac

utterance: "I's gwine to see ef dat's a rat or a evil sperit,'"
speaker: Uncle Isaac

utterance: "Ef you's a rat, I'll know you,'"
speaker: Uncle Isaac

utterance: "Mr. Johnny"—he always used that term when he wanted to gain anything; it recalled old associations-" Mr. Johnny, I's had a mighty bad piece of luck hit me."
speaker: Cal

utterance: "I's done lost meh grandmother,"
speaker: Cal

utterance: "Why, I thought you lost your grandmother two months ago! You buried her, anyhow."
speaker: John

utterance: "Yes, suh. But this is my other grandmother."
speaker: Cal

utterance: "Why, you lost one last winter too, and one- This is the fourth grandmother you have lost, to my certain knowledge."
speaker: John

utterance: "Yes, suh, dat's so. Dat ole man marry mo'n any other man I uver see in de wull, She die' las' night, an' de funeral comes off dis evenin'; an' I thought I'd ax you to let me off dis evenin' to go to it."
speaker: Cal

utterance: "When did she die?"
speaker: John

utterance: "Oh! She died las' night."
speaker: Cal

utterance: "What was the matter with her?"
speaker: John

utterance: "Suh?"
speaker: Cal

utterance: "What was the matter with her?"
speaker: John

utterance: "Oh! I don't know, suh."
speaker: Cal

utterance: "Why didn't you send for me, or mention it before?"
speaker: John

utterance: "Well, you see, suh, she wuz tooken kind o' sudden, jes las' night, an' jes went right off, so."
speaker: Cal

utterance: "They are burying her in a great hurry,”
speaker: John

utterance: "Yes, suh; looks so to me too, I specks dat ole man'll be marryin' agin befo' de week's out. He didn' wait but two weeks las' time; I know he won't wait mo'n a week dis time."
speaker: Cal

utterance: "How about your wedding-suit? Is that all right? Does it fit?"
speaker: John's friends

utterance: "He couldn't git 'long at all widout me. I len's him my clo'es. I's gwine to len' him dis suit to git married in to-morrer."
speaker: Johnsing

utterance: "Oh, shoo, Mr. Johnsing, you's jes foolin' me!"
speaker: the girl

utterance: "No, I ain't; I declare I ain't. Ef I is, I hope de debble may rise right by dat tree an'—"
speaker: Johnsing

utterance: "Mr. Johnny, jes le' me speak to you a minute, will you? Jes step over dis a-way a minute, won't you?"
speaker: Cal

utterance: "Take them off,"
speaker: John

utterance: "Mr. Johnny, jes—"
speaker: Cal

utterance: "Take them off,"
speaker: John

utterance: "Whar, Mr. Johnny?"
speaker: Cal

utterance: "Right where you stand, I'll give you one minute."
speaker: John

utterance: "Yes, suh,"
speaker: Cal

utterance: "Now walk before me,"
speaker: John

utterance: "Colonel, you have had a duel, of course?"
speaker: some one

utterance: "Once."
speaker: Colonel Carter of Cartersville

utterance: "Tell us about it,"
speaker: some one

utterance: "Well, when I was as young and almost as big a fool as some of you are, I thought, like you, duelling was a fine thing. I had read a great deal about it, and talked more. I considered the code the proper recourse of a gentleman, and I so declared myself frequently. This did not prevent me from being disagreeable enough in other ways to get into a number of collisions, in which, as I was a strapping young fellow at the time, I was generally victorious. I was then practising law in the little county town where I started, and I deemed myself easily the greatest lawyer in the circuit, if not in the State. It was necessary to be aggressive, I thought."
speaker: Colonel Carter of Cartersville

utterance: "(If there were no women and no fools, there'd be no duels, gentlemen.)"
speaker: Colonel Carter of Cartersville

utterance: "Did you tell him where to send?'
speaker: Jim Burton and Lindman

utterance: "Of course, I told him we would sit here all night.'"
speaker: Jim Burton

utterance: "That's right,'"
speaker: Jim Burton and Lindman

utterance: "And he as good as kicked me out of his house, sir,'"
speaker: Jim Burton

utterance: "What!'"
speaker: Jim Burton and Lindman

utterance: "'Of course he did not lay his hand on me, but he rang the bell, and told that black butler of his to show me the door.'"
speaker: Jim Burton

utterance: "Jim, whom did he say he would send for?'"
speaker: Jim Burton and Lindman

utterance: "I did not catch the name exactly, but it sounded like "Drace"; it could not have been him, though; he's the sheriff!'"
speaker: Jim Burton

utterance: "'Drace! Are you sure it was Drace? There's only one Drace in the county, and that's the sheriff!'"
speaker: Jim Burton and Lindman

utterance: "Why in the mischief did you tell him where we were?'"
speaker: Jim Burton and Lindman

utterance: "Suppose old Facton should choose shot-guns and buckshot? He's one of the best shots with a shot-gun in the world, one-armed or no one-armed.'"
speaker: Jim Burton

utterance: "Get out of the window, hurry; go to Rice's loft. I'll hold it. I'll keep the scoundrels out.'"
speaker: Lindman

utterance: "Jim, you talk as if you were drunk now.'"
speaker: Jim Burton and Lindman

utterance: "What became of your old sweetheart, Colonel, for whom you fought?"
speaker: some one

utterance: "She married a Methodist preacher, and went as a missionary to China,"
speaker: Colonel Carter of Cartersville
